Anybody out there have any ideas?

Posts.Content: May 3, 2009 06:46PM lmt041409 wrote: Hey Cherneski, I get through by living one day at a time. Ever since I got the Diagnosis on April 14, I have focused on each day--one day at a time.  My surgery is tomorrow so I'll focus on getting to the hospital and surviving all they will do before my surgery at 10:30. I'm having a lumpectomy and SNB. I'm actually looking forward to the best sleep I've ever had when I am in surgery! I wish you peace! And luck on your surgery day!
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 10, 2009 08:53PM lmt041409 wrote: Don23  I know what you mean by waiting. I was doing well at taking things one day at a time. I had a lumpectomy and SNB last Monday. Since the surgery, I've not felt as patient. It was a stark realization that this journey has just begun and was not near the end at the point of surgery!  So I want to GET IT OUT TOO-- and move on with life. I was off work all week so maybe once I return on Tuesday after the surgeon's follow-up, I'll be distracted by work things and won't be marking the calendar based on onc appts, chem(if I have to have), radiation, and tamoxifen.  Good luck and try to take it one day at a time.
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 04:24PM lmt041409 wrote: I'm a June girl too. Start June 4, 6 rounds of TCH every 21 days. I opted to NOT get a port because it freaked me out too! AFter that, I have seven weeks of rads. The closer the day gets the more anxious and worried I become. Good idea about reading the April and May posts! Thanks!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2009 11:28PM lmt041409 wrote: Woo Hoo, Pinkmama! Glad it went well. I'm having the same treatment as you. It really is doable. I'm having more problems with my head--want my real life back, afraid of the unknown SEs, etc. Not like me to be a downer but stayed home from work two days this week. I have a wonderful boss those which helps immensely. I will definitely look for Oasis; detested the biotene mouthwash although I'm still using the toothpase. Tried to have pizza and one beer last night. Not a good idea. Diarrhea off and on since. Back to my motto of small frequent meals. My mouth is getting a little weird too. Can't drink anything carbonated anymore and seem to prefer things that are NOT sweet. Actually just got up and made myself a virgin bloody mary--the big glass of iced tea I had is keeping me awake. Keep strong! I like jug-r-naughts too!!! Too funny. Linda
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2009 10:20PM lmt041409 wrote: I am pretty sure the Look Good Feel Better program is sponsored by the American Cancer Society. At least it was were I went on May 18. Great makeup from lots of great namebrand companies and the opportunity to get a free wig. They had a catalog called TLC that you can find on the American Cancer Society website that shows wigs, scarves, etc. I received my It's a Wrap headwrap in the mail today. It is beautiful, very very nice. www.franceluxe.com and then look at the Good Wishes program. This program was founded by Laurie Erickson. Several woman at her office even signed the card for me. Very very nice experience! I think the reason chemo is harder than surgery is because of the day to day unknown. Will I feel good? Will I be sick? What next? At least with the surgery you want the beast out and you know surgery will take care of that! But with chemo, it's a long scary haul. I'm on day 8 of my first of six rounds of taxotere, carboplatin, and herceptin and haven't felt too bad. A little nausea, some bone pain from neulasta, a couple of days of serious chemo brain and now diarrhea but if I keep having the experience I've been having the last week, I will feel blessed! Linda T
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2009 07:55PM lmt041409 wrote: Hi Zuzee. I had infusion in my hand. I heard that they start low and can go up with each infusion. They put a warming pad on my hand to get my veins to come to the surface.  I am Day 14 and feeling pretty good! No hair coming out yet but I think I heard tomorrow is the day that might start. I had scheduled appt with my hairdresser for tomorrow night to have hair shaved but the wig didn't come in and my family and I decided it would be less traumatic to do it at home. Next tx is Thursday, June 25. Onc said hair would surely be gone after that one. Once it starts coming out, we're shaving it--I don't want to experience the clumps! I would have to say I felt almostly totally myself by Day 8. A little nausea when I wake up but I eat small meals all day long and that seems to take care of it. All of the SE's were annoying but doable! Hugs to all! Linda
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2009 08:55PM lmt041409 wrote: Day two after first chemo. The infusion went fine--no bad effects during infusion. Had pre-meds, EMEND, anti itching, more steroids, etc. Not bad at all. Had a tiny queasy stomach later last night. Took Claritin last night to prepare for Neulasta shot. Went back today for Neulasta shot and have slowly been feeling worse as the day has progressed. The nurse told me I would feel flu-like and I am but nothing I can't deal with. Another Claritin and some ibuprofen. Face and chest is flushed--I'm told by the nurse it is from the steroids. Did manage to take the dogs for a walk today with my DH. I've been eating small meals all day long and drinking plenty of fluids. So far so good!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2009 09:00PM lmt041409 wrote: Jo, Sorry Taxatere was not good for you. How did it go today?

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2009 07:20PM lmt041409 wrote: Thanks, Rinna! I go tomorrow morning and am pretty nervous! But like you said, waiting around to GET sick is probably more nerve wracking than actually getting sick! MamaQ--good luck tomorrow, too! I'll think of you during the day wondering where you are in your chemo. I have 10:30am appt with doc and then whenever they start chemo I'll be there 3 hours--taxotere, carboplatin, and herceptin.

Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 04:27PM lmt041409 wrote: Bonnid, The American Cancer society will give you a free wig! I went to one of their Look Good, Feel Better events and they are ordering one for me out of their catalog. They have some really cute ones and why not get one free! Also, www.franceluxe.com and Good Wishes program will send you a free headwrap. I'm not much of a hat girl so I am looking at scarves and the wig, I think.

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2009 04:49PM lmt041409 wrote: Candy, Some blood pressure meds DO cause coughing. Your doc can give you a different on. I was having coughing which we eventualy tied to silent GERD but she changed my BP meds at the same time saying that some cause coughing. Don't remember what I was taking but am taking Cozaar and a small amount of diruretic now.  Linda T (lmt041409)
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2009 06:20PM lmt041409 wrote: Haven't been on for awhile but have a couple of questions. On Day Ten of Chemo #4 of 6--is it OK to visit a patient in the hospital? My step-dad is in skilled nursing for bone infection and daily antibiotic IV. When I went to the hospital for a fever Fourth of July Weekend they had me cover my mouth and nose with a wet washcloth when I walked into the ER and then told me to ask for a mask immediately. Oh, by the way, I did get the dreaded Neulasta shot on Day 2. Will my hubby and I ever been interested in sex again? I'm beginning to feel like a virgin with no idea that sex is so great and that just isn't like me........ Thanks!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2009 09:36PM lmt041409 wrote: Hey June Bugs! Glad everyone is surviving our June Start chemo! I am on Day Six and feeling pretty good! Did have some of the bone pain with Neulasta shot. Took Claritin day before, day of and day after and then switched to ibuprofen. Today my tongue and mouth feel a little sore--kind of like when you burn your mouth on hot chocolate but not quite that bad. I tried biotene toothpaste and mouthwash from chemo day till yesterday and I'm rebelling. Can't stand the taste--it is hitting the garbage! In general foods are beginning to taste weird. Went back to work today all day. I've been trying to eat small frequent meals. Worried that work might get in the way of taking care of me and was a little concerned I might feel nauseous if I didn't eat small meals but I managed! Felt a little pissy today moodwise but DH took me out for dinner and I noticed it felt really good to feel normal--pizza and beer!! Onc says no dietary restrictions. Of course, I will not eat that too often! MamaQ, glad they finally got your cocktail right just for you! Hopefully round two will be better for you. My crappy mood today and yesterday was really the first time I've felt angry/negative throughout this whole ordeal. I've been so positive up till now. Not knowing from day to day what side effects might come along is annoying at best! Have a great hump day tomorrow. Linda T
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: May 27, 2009 10:36PM lmt041409 wrote: I went to the Look Good Feel Better event that same day I found out I had to have chemo and would lose my hair so I was pretty emotional. The woman from the American Cancer Society was very nice and there were several volunteers there who helped people with their makeup and wigs. They gave us each a makeup kit for our skin color and many of the women got to take a wig home. I wanted a wig that is very much like my own hair, short and spikey and salt and pepper. They are ordering it for me tomorrow--apparently they only place a wig order once a month. I should get it in time for my June 18 appt with my hairdresser to have her shave off my hair (have my first chemo June 4) and style/cut my wig. The event was a good experience--four breast cancer gals and three lung We were supposed to see a brief 3 minute(?) video but the machine wouldn't work. It was a great evening. And hey, I like playing with makeup!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: May 12, 2009 12:37AM lmt041409 wrote: Yes, I wonder when it will feel real,too. I was diagnosed April 14, and had a lumpectomy and SNB last Monday,May 4. I'll see the surgeon tomorrow, May 12 re the pathology report. I have already decided if he has to go back in, I am having a bilat Mastectomy with no reconstruction. I have been a little down the last few days. I think in my mind I thought the surgery was the end even though I knew for sure I'd have to have radiation and tamoxifen. But now that the surgery is over, I realize this is just the beginning!!! I read somewhere that each milestone--surgery, rads, chem, etc--causes us to feel a little more down that usual. So even though you know what is going to happen it still all feels fuzzy! I like the Cleopatra, Queen of DeNile!! That is cute! Gotta found some humor in this! I guess I still try to live one day at a time.
Posts.Title: When does it feel real? PS73 Makratz

Posts.Content: May 12, 2009 12:14AM lmt041409 wrote: My stereotactic biopsy wasn't bad at all. I took an anti-anxiey med before I went though and I really think it helps. I had mine on a Thursday and got a call from my doctor the following Tueday. I didn't expect that there would be any bad news and put it out of my mind. Mine was malignant. What a shocker that phone call was! Had surgery on May 4 and will find out tomorrow if  they were able to get it all out!
Posts.Title: Radial Scar and Stereotopic Biopsy stef58 stef58

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2009 11:56PM lmt041409 wrote: What does the Ativan help with? I just got EMEND in my IV, and to take Day Two and Three. I took Compazine Sunday and Monday but it makes me sleep the day away. Wouldn't mind that but it's a little hard to sleep at work! Tee hee! I did eat a small scrap of fresh ginger this morning and it seems to help the nausea quickly. Linda T
